question: In cancer models, does atypical protein kinase C zeta (PKCζ) promote tumor growth by reprogramming glutamine metabolism? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Interestingly, the loss of PKCζ in mice results in enhanced intestinal tumorigenesis and increased levels of these two metabolic enzymes, whereas patients with low levels of PKCζ have a poor prognosis.
content.source_2: Pharmacologic activation of PKCζ under nutrient stress boosted glutamine utilization by upregulating glutaminase activity, which in turn accelerated tumor growth in colorectal cancer models and xenografts.
content.source_3: Taken together, this demonstrates that PKCζ is a critical metabolic tumor suppressor in mouse and human cancer.
content.source_4: Across a prospective patient cohort, high PKCζ expression was associated with increased glutamine uptake and shorter survival, and ectopic PKCζ expression in vivo increased tumor volume by approximately 40% through enhanced glutamine catabolism.
